dialogue_line_replacements.text: ¡Buenos días! Me llamo Ana. ¿Y tú, cómo te llamas?
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: Good morning! My name is Ana. And you, what's your name?

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: In Puerto Rico, greetings are warm and often loud — enthusiasm is welcomed. '¿Qué es la que hay?' or '¿Qué hay de nuevo?' are casual alternatives to '¿Cómo estás?'. Strangers are often greeted with 'Buenas' at any time of day.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: A hug (abrazo) and cheek kiss are common even on first meetings in social settings. In Puerto Rico, physical warmth in greetings is a sign of friendliness, not overfamiliarity.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: Subject pronouns are frequently used before verbs in PR Spanish: '¿Cómo tú estás?' instead of '¿Cómo estás?'. This is a distinctive Caribbean Spanish feature. 'Mira' (look) is often used to get attention before speaking.
